body:
Implying that I or others don't care about such? That's basically a back-handed ad hominem attack. We can be more civil than that, can't we?

["foo", "bar"].include?("blech") says the same thing as "blech".either?(["foo", "bar"]). Yes, a different object receives the message. The receiver of the object is essentially irrelevant as both representations are idempotent.
On Sunday, April 10, 2011 at 1:55 PM, dhh wrote: 
> in? and either? puts the argument you care about front and center. When you're calling it this way, you care about the object of the method, not the parameter. So if you do array.include?(object), it means you care primarily about whether the array has the object. If you do object.in?(array), you care primarily about whether the object is in the array.
> 
> You could slash about 70% of what we love about Ruby if you didn't care about such subtle arguments for expressiveness. I'm proud to say that I do.
